etymologies: Old English hwæs, genitive of hwā ‘who’ and hwæt ‘what’

notes.text: On the differences in use between whose and who's, see who's

definitions: belonging to or associated with which person

examples.text: a car was parked at the curb and Juliet wondered whose it was

shortDefinitions: belonging to or associated with which person

definitions: of whom or which (used to indicate that the following noun belongs to or is associated with the person or thing mentioned in the previous clause)

examples.text: he's a man whose opinion I respect
a willow tree whose branches reached right to the ground
